tossups.question: At Princeton, this man was roommates and wrestling partners with Frank Carlucci, the future Secretary of Defence. He first achieved his highest post through the non-Angolan “Halloween Massacre,” and he released a solitaire app in 2016 based on a version played by Winston Churchill. (*) He remarked “stuff happens” about looters of a national museum and served in his highest post for both Ford and George W Bush. This man expounded on “known knowns” and “unknown knowns” in a briefing about WMDs. For 10 points, name this former US Defence Secretary and architect of the Iraq War.

M.V. Clarke links a banner in this work with Philippe de Mézières’s call for a crusade. While cleaning this work, Dillian Gordon discovered a small island depicted in a previously opaque orb. Three saints in this painting hold the Agnus Dei, a ring, and an arrow as they (*) present the main figure to the Virgin and Child with eleven angels wearing white hart badges in the other panel. Edward the Confessor, Edmund the Martyr, and John the Baptist glorify Richard II in, for 10 points, this painting, an English International Gothic diptych.
tossups.answer: The Wilton Diptych [“Diptych” is not necessary in the answer after “diptych” is read; prompt on partial answer prior to that] <LC>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Wilton Diptych <LC> [“Diptych” is not necessary in the answer after “diptych” is read; prompt on partial answer prior to that]

tossups.question: A ruler of this city is said to have enjoyed getting debtors drunk and then setting up an iron maiden-like device disguised as his promiscuous wife. Pyrrhus of Epirus disastrously attempted to install Cleonymus as king of this city, which was subdued with the defeat of Nabis. An earthquake that struck this city in 464 BCE coincided with a (*) revolt whose survivors settled at Naupactos. This city was ruled by the Agiad and Eurypontid dynasties, and its constitution was devised by Lykourgos. For 10 points, helots served this famously terse polis, at one point led by Leonidas.

This person once wrote to the president of Proctor & Gamble to make a complaint about an Ivory soap commercial. Jason Sudeikis tells this person they are “way too cute to be just a FedEx girl” in Horrible Bosses. This person is called for by Tate Ellington at a bar in (*) Remember Me, which was produced by this person’s first husband. Her “little engine that could” The Tig was closed last year after this person was presented with a ring featuring two diamonds that belonged to Diana, Princess of Wales. For ten points, name this former Suits star and fiancée of Prince Harry.

This mountain range was explored in 1856-7 by Semyonov, who took the name of this range as an epithet, and Tömür [tuhr-mooer], is the highest point of this range. To the north of this mountain range lies the Junggar Basin and to the south is the (*) Tarim Basin, containing the Taklamakan Desert, which separates this range from the Tibetan Plateau. Part of the Greater Himalaya, this mountain range connects to the Pamirs in the south, and the Altai in the east. For 10 points, name this range in the Xinjiang [shin-jee-ang] Autonomous Region of China, whose name means ‘Heavenly Mountain’.
tossups.answer: Tian Shan (accept Heavenly Mountain(s) until mentioned) <CB>

tossups.question: A symphony by this composer has a D minor finale based on a chaconne from Gluck’s Don Juan, and is subtitled “Della casa del diavolo”. While not Saint-Saëns, this composer used bird-calls in a piece nicknamed the “Aviary”, and his output was catalogued by Yves Gérard. This composer featured church bells and military bugles in his (*) “Nocturnal Music of the Streets of Madrid”, and included castanets in the fandango final movement of his fourth guitar quintet. For 10 points, name this composer who wrote a famous String Quintet in E Major, the minuet of which deceives Mrs Wilberforce in The Ladykillers.

In a surreal section of the work containing this character, he testifies that the protagonist is “bisexually abnormal” and “more sinned against than sinning”. This character is based on Oliver St. John Gogarty, a classicist who also briefly went to Oxford, where this character meets Haines. This character often swims in the Forty Foot, and after listening to a theory on Shakespeare, suggests that (*) Molly’s husband may have homosexual designs on “Kinch”. First seen calling Stephen Dedalus to join him on the roof with his shaving bowl, for 10 points, name this medical student whose name follows “stately, plump” in the opening line of Ulysses.
tossups.answer: Buck Mulligan [accept either name, or Malachi Mulligan] <ADG>

tossups.question: Attempts at this action became more popular following early 1960, when it was performed by Russian- born vegetarian Barbara Moore. The ACU prohibited attempts at completing this action after Ivan Hart-Davies was found to have broken the speed limit during his attempt. (*) In 2013, Sean Conway did this action in 135 days by swimming up the Irish Sea. Motorised attempts at this action usually begin by using the A30, and end using the A9. For ten points, name this journey from the southwesternmost settlement of Great Britain to the northeasternmost.
tossups.answer: Travelling between Land’s End and John O’Groats (or vice versa) [Prompt on people who start being pedantic about Duncansby Head etc; prompt (what specific journey?) on stuff like “travelling across Britain”] <JK>
tossups.answer_formatted: Travelling between Land’s End and John O’Groats <JK> [Prompt on people who start being pedantic about Duncansby Head etc; prompt (what specific journey?) on stuff like “travelling across Britain”]
acceptable: Travelling between Land’s End and John O’Groats <JK>
Travelling between Land’s End and John O’Groats <JK>

tossups.question: One of this author’s plays ends with the line “Most of us lie to ourselves, darling, most of us”, spoken by boarding house-owner Constance Tuckerman. This author’s depiction of an anti-Nazi named Julia in her memoir Pentimento was shown to be a lie by Mary (*) McCarthy. This author of The Autumn Garden described Mary Tilford accusing her teachers of being lesbian lovers in one work, while in another of her plays, the Hubbards’ cotton mill plans are disrupted by Regina Giddens. For 10 points, name this playwright of The Children’s Hour and The Little Foxes.

In one work, a group of characters achieve this feat when their ship is lifted by a waterspout and encounter an army of ant-cavalry and lettuce-winged birds. In addition to A True Story, in another work, a capsule coated with Cavorite allows Bedford and Cavor to do this. In a series of two novels, an enormous (*) cannon is built by the Baltimore Gun Club to allow three men to perform this action “From the Earth”. For 10 points, name this feat described in works by H. G. Wells and Jules Verne, involving making a journey first undertaken by Michael Collins, Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong.
tossups.answer: travel to the Moon [accept any answer that implies motion towards and eventual arrival at the Moon] <YY>
tossups.answer_formatted: travel to the Moon <YY> [accept any answer that implies motion towards or eventual arrival at the Moon]
acceptable: any answer that implies motion towards

tossups.question: In one work from this country, a gabbering character claims to be able to juggle apples with each foot on a different horse. One work from this country involves a Saracen slave girl who turns out to be the daughter of a Carthaginian king; that work alternates between sections titled “now they say and (*) tell and relate” and “now they sing”. In a work from this country sometimes attributed to Turold, the title owner of Durandal blows a horn too hard, and dies at Roncevaux Pass. For 10 points, name this modern-day home country of chansons de geste like The Song of Roland.

Marilyn Strathern defined the “limits” of approaches to anthropology of these people pioneered by Carolyn Ellis. “Glimpses of the Unmentionable” title an Edmund Leach talk on the social networks of these people. In Time and the Other, Johannes Fabian argues that these people “deny coevalness” with their objects, (*) and post-colonialists have called them “handmaidens of imperialism.” Darkness in El Dorado accused two of them of promoting conflict among the Yanomamo. For 10 points, name these people, who include Napoleon Chagnon and Margaret Mead.
tossups.answer: anthropologists [also accept ethnographers; accept yourself until “social networks” and do not accept or prompt thereafter; also accept people at home until “handmaidens of imperialism” and do not accept or prompt thereafter; anti-prompt on any more specific types of people who do anthropology or ethnography] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: anthropologists <JG> [also accept ethnographers; accept yourself until “social networks or do not or or prompt thereafter; also accept people at home until “handmaidens of imperialism” and do not accept or prompt thereafter; anti-prompt on any more specific types of people who do anthropology or ethnography]

tossups.question: In one musical, two characters advocate this action by noting that “at Wanamaker’s and Saks and Klein’s/a lesson I’ve been taught/you can’t get alterations on a dress you haven’t bought.” A character in Cabaret sings that with this action “the old despair/that was often there/suddenly ceases to be.” (*) Bobby asks for this to be done to him “a little” after Amy sings, in a frantic patter song, “thank you all/for the gifts and flowers/thank you all now/it’s back to the showers” because she is not doing this “today” in Company. For 10 points, name this action which Tevye’s daughters do without a matchmaker.
tossups.answer: marry someone [accept word forms or with any direct object] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: marry someone <JG> [accept word formsaccept with any direct object]

tossups.question: The 1792 Manchester and Salford Police Act granted Police Commissioners the power to construct these things, and recover the cost of construction from owners of adjoining properties. Thomas Hawksley opposed Edwin Chadwick’s support for a velocity-augmenting design of these things. (*) Hydraulic lime mortar was typically used in the construction of these things, although Portland cement was employed in an extensive system of these things whose construction was overseen by the Metropolitan Board of Works. Joseph Bazalgette designed, for 10 points, London’s system of which wastewater-carrying structures?
tossups.answer: Sewers [accept drains; accept sewerage systems or equivalents; prompt on gutters] <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: Sewers <HO> [accept drains; accept sewerage systems or equivalents; prompt on gutters]

tossups.question: In Rome, devotees of a companion of this deity like the hastiferi would mutilate their arms on the day before Hilaria. Zeus once broke up a fight between this god, his son Cycnus, and Heracles with a lightning bolt. The giant Aloadai [uh-LOH-wuh-dye] locked this deity in an urn for over a year. (*) Companions of this deity include Bellona and he was served in Rome by “leaping priests” called the Salii. This father of Phobos and Deimos was once caught in a net in bed with their mother. For 10 points, name this frequent lover of Aphrodite and god of war.
tossups.answer: Ares [and/or Mars; also accept any of Bellona, Cybele, Ma, or Magna Mater until “Cycnus” given the tremendous amount of controversy over whom Hilaria celebrated and whom the hastiferi served, but do not accept or prompt thereafter] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Ares <JG> [and/or Mars; also accept any of Bellona, Cybele, Ma, or Magna Mater until “Cycnus” given the tremendous amount of controversy over whom Hilaria celebrated and whom the hastiferi served, but do not accept or prompt thereafter]

tossups.question: This animal can lay up to 3 hundred million eggs at once, the most of any egg laying species, and its Latin name stems from a word for a millstone. This animal has the fewest vertebrae of any fish, at 13, and this animal lacks both a swim bladder and a (*) tail, steering instead with anal and dorsal fins. This animal was falsely thought to only move through gliding on ocean currents, and this animal maintains its body heat by presenting its large side-profile towards the sun. The heaviest of bony fish, for 10 points name this animal known for its flat, disk-like appearance.

One type of these objects are characterised by a hilar appendage on their surface and are produced in basidia. Several wood wasp species in the Sirex genus inject these objects along with their eggs into the sapwood of pine trees. (*) Chytrids can generate motile examples of these objects which possess a flagellum. These objects can be dispersed from lamellae on the underside of the caps of agarics, or they are emitted in response to rainfall by mature puffballs. For 10 points, name these structures used for asexual reproduction by ferns and fungi.

This thinker referred to his exegetical approach as “enculage” [on-kyoo-LAHJ] or “buggery.” In a work titled [this thinker]: The Clamor of Being, Alain Badiou attacked this thinker as a crypto-monist. This non-Derrida thinker tried to isolate “difference in itself” in Difference and Repetition. With (*) an alphabetically later co-author, this thinker proposed a “body without organs” and critiqued “tree-like” ideas of knowledge in favor of a “rhizomatic” one in A Thousand Plateaus and Anti-Oedipus. For 10 points, name this post-structuralist collaborator of Felix Guattari.

The Short Creek raids targeted groups who performed this action, many of whom used revelations received by John Taylor as their justification. The Edmunds-Tucker Act supported a ban on this practice that was was upheld in Reynolds v. U.S. This practice, known as “the Principle”, was (*) common among early groups driven out of Nauvoo, but is now only carried out by fundamentalist sects like the Apostolic United Brethren and disavowed by Thomas Monson. For 10 points, name this practice in which Mormons take multiple wives.
tossups.answer: polygamy [accept descriptions, accept polygyny, accept bigamy] <EJW>

tossups.question: This architect used the concept of a “Metonymic Landscape” for Seoul’s Dongdaemun Design Plaza. This architect’s design for the Cardiff Bay Opera House lacked financial support and has never been realised, and plans for a bicycle helmet-shaped stadium in Meiji Park by this architect have also been scrapped. (*) This architect’s completed projects include the BMW Central Building in Leipzig, and the “twin boulders” of Guangzhou Opera House. The designer of the London 2012 Aquatics Centre and the 2022 FIFA World Cup Stadium, for 10 points, name this Pritzker-winning female architect.

The losers of one battle of this name blamed Nikolaus von Renys for prematurely lowering his banner. A battle of this name’s victors gained critical intelligence from a note on an officer killed in the preceding Battle of Gumbinnen. Alexander Samsonov committed suicide over that battle of this name, (*) which was followed by the Masurian Lakes campaign. Wladyslaw II Jagiello and Vytautas the Great won a battle of this name also called the Battle of Grunwald. For 10 points, give this common name of a 1914 loss for the Russian Empire and a 1410 defeat for the Teutonic Knights.
tossups.answer: Tannenberg [accept Grunwald or Zalgiris until “Gumbinnen” and prompt until “Grunwald” is mentioned] <SC>
tossups.answer_formatted: Tannenberg <SC> [accept Grunwald or Zalgiris until “Gumbinnen or prompt until “Grunwald” is mentioned]

tossups.question: This technique is used to estimate defect concentrations in carbon nanotubes by measure the ratios of the G and D peaks. A normal mode must transform with the same symmetry as the quadratic forms to be active in this technique. Molecules undergoing this technique must have anisotropic polarisability. (*) Rayleigh-scattered light must be separated out in order to observe Stokes shifts in this technique. For 10 points, name this technique which relies on inelastic scattering of photons by electrons and named for an Indian scientist.

The first product this man advertised was “invisible ink”, and he set up a pharmaceutical company that funded the development of antitoxins for tetanus, diphtheria, and gas gangrene with Silas Burroughs. Red or Dead’s HIV awareness sandals and the papers of (*) Francis Crick are items included in a London library named for this man. For ten points, name this pharmaceutical entrepreneur and collector whose legacy includes a trust dedicated to biomedical research.

A model of this phenomenon in a free Fermi gas of electrons in a uniform magnetic field is named for Lev Landau. This property names a type of shielding where electron circulation within an s orbital causes upfield shifting of local nuclei. Materials with this property will display a negative weight change in a (*) Gouy balance, as their magnetic susceptibility is negative. In the Meissner effect, superconductors “perfectly” display this phenomenon and expel all magnetic fields. For 10 points, name this property of materials which repel an applied magnetic field.

bonuses.leadin: In Stan Barstow’s novel A Kind of Loving, the draughtsman Vic Brown is compelled by social expectation to marry his girlfriend Ingrid after he causes her to end up in this state. For 10 points each:
answers: pregnancy [accept word forms; accept expecting a child; accept baser synonyms]
parts: Identify this state, which also facilitates Joe Lampton’s swift marriage to the wealthy businessman’s daughter Susan Brown in John Braine’s Room at the Top.
In this 1958 play set in Salford, the seventeen-year-old Jo becomes pregnant by a black sailor. Dramatist Shelagh Delaney wrote this kitchen sink drama at the age of just eighteen.

This 1960 novel by Lynne Reid Banks also concerns an unmarried woman who finds herself in the family way. In the novel, Jane Graham is thrown out of her home by her father and moves into the title lodgings.
answers_formatted: pregnancy [accept word forms; accept expecting a child; accept baser synonyms]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about attempted political unions and federations in Africa:
answers: the Central African Republic [also accept any of the CAR; la République Centrafricaine; or the Ködörösêse tî Bêafrîka] (the “United States of Latin Africa” was supposed to have included every Romance language-speaking country in Central Africa, from Chad to Angola. It obviously got nowhere) <JG>
parts: The short-lived Union of African States, an attempted transnational Pan-African federation, was the brainchild of Ahmed Sékou Touré, Modibo Keïta, and this first leader of an independent Ghana.

Modibo Keïta, this country’s first president, had earlier led a union between Senegal and this country that lasted all of two months. Tuareg rebels declared an independent state of Azawad in its north in 2012.

This country’s first Prime Minister, Barthélemy Boganda, proposed a “United States of Latin Africa” before dying in a plane crash. François Bozizé’s 2003 coup in this country has led to an ongoing series of civil wars.
answers_formatted: the Central African Republic <JG> [also accept any of the CAR; la République Centrafricaine; or the Ködörösêse tî Bêafrîka]
metadata: the “United States of Latin Africa” was supposed to have included every Romance language-speaking country in Central Africa, from Chad to Angola. It obviously got nowhere

bonuses.leadin: Accelerating charges emit electromagnetic radiation. For 10 points each::
parts: The angular distribution of this radiation pattern is isotropic in the plane perpendicular to the emitter. Its Hertzian form is generated by an oscillating current passing between two time-varying charges.
This monochromatic radiation is emitted when a charged particle is placed into a B field and travels in circular orbits at speeds much smaller than the speed of light.
This radiation is emitted by a particle which exceeds the speed of light in the medium in which it travels. It is responsible for the blue glow around nuclear reactors.

bonuses.leadin: The English Civil War and its aftermath saw the emergence of a number of politico-religious dissenting groups. Name some of them, for 10 points each:
answers: the Quakers [or the Society of Friends]
parts: This group, founded by George Fox, were perhaps the most successful of the dissenting sects in that they still exist. They are known for their pacifism, and for founding Pennsylvania.

This group expressed its views in the Agreement of the People, championing popular sovereignty, legal equality, and religious tolerance. They are named for their supposed desire to put all of society on an equal footing.

This antinomian group was founded by two London tailors and drew on the ideas of the earlier ‘Ranters’. This group, unlike the Quakers, claimed that God existed in the form of a glorified body, and was not purely spiritual.

bonuses.leadin: This poet compared love to “fish and chips on winter nights” and “blankets full of strange delights”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British Beat poet of “Love Is” and “I Want to Print”, who spent the 1970s in a relationship with Carol Ann Duffy.
Henri was a poet from this British city, where he came to prominence as part of its Merseybeat movement.
Henri co-authored the collection The Mersey Sound with Brian Patten and this other poet, who wrote “Let me die a young man’s death.” He also presents Poetry Please on Radio 4.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about some Australian plebiscites:
answers: Conscription [accept compulsory military service or other equivalent descriptions]
Postal votes [accept mail; accept any answer implying the involvement of the Australian postal service] <HO>
parts: The first two non-binding Australian plebiscites concerned the proposed introduction of this measure. Both plebiscites on this measure were announced by Prime Minister Billy Hughes.
The third plebiscite held in Australia was held alongside a 1977 referendum, and resulted in this song being chosen by the public to replace God Save the Queen as the Australian national anthem.

In 2017, a plebiscite was held in Australia on the question of whether same-sex marriage should be legalised. Votes in the plebiscite were submitted by this means, which entailed a $80 million cost to the government.
answers_formatted: Postal votes <HO> [accept mail; accept any answer implying the involvement of the Australian postal service]
acceptable: any answer implying the involvement of the Australian postal service

bonuses.leadin: In one myth, one of these people from Nubia challenges the Pharoah’s court to read a scroll strapped to his chest without opening it, which Si-Osire achieves before burning the Nubian and himself to nothing. For 10 points each:
answers: magicians [or sorcerers; accept any remotely close description of stuff like that; grudgingly prompt on priests given some of the stories in the Westcar Papyrus]
Setne Khaemweset [accept either underlined portion with absolutely any vowel choices since nobody knows what they actually are]
parts: The Westcar Papyrus contains several myths of boneheaded Pharoahs interacting with these people. Si-Osire shows his father the underworld and turns out to be the reincarnation of one who protects Egypt from Nubian ones.

Si-Osire is the son of this historical prince, who in another myth ends up on the street with his penis stuck in a pot after dreaming that he gave up his possessions and watched a woman kill his family in order to sleep with her.

That dream was a warning to Setne to return a book named for this god to the tomb of Neferkaptah. This god of magic, knowledge, scribes, and the moon is usually depicted as a baboon or with the head of an ibis.
answers_formatted: magicians [or sorcerers; accept any remotely close description of stuff like that; grudgingly prompt on priests given some of the stories in the Westcar Papyrus]
Setne Khaemweset [accept either underlined portion with absolutely any vowel choices since nobody knows what they actually are]
acceptable: any remotely close description of stuff like that
either underlined portion with absolutely any vowel choices

bonuses.leadin: This work opens with the proclamation of the text “Deus in adjutorium”, after which the choir enters accompanied by trumpet fanfares. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this composition of 1610. It includes the duet “Pulchra es” and concludes with a long setting of the Magnificat.
The Vespers of 1610 were written by this Italian composer, whose operas include The Coronation of Poppea and L’Orfeo.

The motet Nigra sum from Monteverdi’s vespers is written for this voice part. The opening recitative “Comfort ye, my people” from Handel’s Messiah was written for this voice part, as well as the part of Aeneas in Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel obtains his tobacco from two inseparable Estonians, and makes friends with a funny Latvian named Kilgas. For 10 points each:
answers: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich
gulag [prompt on things like work camp]
parts: Name this novel in which Alyosha the Baptist, Fetyukov and Gopchik work alongside the protagonist laying bricks in the cold.

Ivan Denisovich spends his day in one of these miserable places. Another of Alexander Solzhenitsyn’s works is titled for an “archipelago” of these places where Soviet dissidents were worked to extreme pain and death.

This novel by Vladimir Sorokin also takes place over the course of 24 grim Russian hours, as its title henchman navigates his daily grind of arson, murder, and glow-in-the-dark genitalia in 2028 Moscow.
answers_formatted: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich
acceptable: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich
One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich

bonuses.leadin: This thinker liked to use weird pseudo-mathematical symbols, for example ‘$ < > a’ meaning ‘fantasy’, as well as his ‘graph of desire’. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French psychoanalyst, who pioneered the idea of the mirror stage in his gloriously impenetrable Écrits.

Lacan gave an influential series of seminars in Paris from 1953 to 1981, in an effort to return to the ideas of this Austrian founder of psychoanalysis. He postulated the Oedipus complex and the id, ego and superego.

Lacan also reinterpreted the object relation, building on the works of this other psychoanalyst. This author of The Psychoanalysis of Children feuded with Anna Freud when they proposed that the superego existed from birth.

bonuses.leadin: Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water, here’s some bonuses about dangerous water features of the British Isles. For 10 points each:
parts: The 9m-wide River Wharfe narrows to a metre-wide rapid called the Strid whence none escape, a mile north of an abbey of this name in Yorkshire. A large Lancashire town of this name is ten miles north-west of Manchester.
The third-largest whirlpool in the world is found in this strait of the Inner Hebrides, which separates Jura and Scarba. A strong tidal race in this strait can give rise to waves nine metres high.

This county’s Broomway causeway connects Wakering Stairs to Foulness Island, and is believed to have killed hundreds of people over the years. The nearest large towns include Basildon, Maldon and Southend in this county.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some bonuses about the ridiculous misadventures of Moḥammad ‘Abdullah Naṣr, affectionately known in Egypt as “Shaykh Mīzō,” [MEE-zoo] which roughly translates to “Dr. Talks-Out-His-Ass.” For 10 points each:
answers: Ḥadīth [also accept Ṣaḥīḥ in context; the technically correct plural of “Ḥadīth” is ’aḥādīth but obviously accept Ḥadīths] (the “other victim” is the telesecularist TV host Islām al-Buḥayrī, whom Sisi pardoned)

Jāmi‘at al-Azhar al-Sharīf [or the Honorable Al-Azhar University] (While debating this point on television, Mizo once infamously allegedly threatened to beat up his interlocutor with an offstage hammer) <JG>
parts: In 2016, Shaykh Mīzō claimed to be this eschatological figure on Facebook, using the watertight logic that his name is Moḥammad ibn ‘Abdullah. This figure will fight al-Masīḥ al-Dajjāl with Jesus in the end times.

Less humorously, that claim got Mīzō arrested in Sisi’s accelerating enforcement of blasphemy laws, another victim of which called al-Bukhārī, who compiled several of these stories about Muḥammad, a “garbage collector.”

One of Mīzō’s more reasonable claims was that this institution, his alma mater, influences Islamic extremism. This Cairo institution is one of the world’s oldest and most influential centers of Islamic scholarship.
answers_formatted: Ḥadīth [also accept Ṣaḥīḥ in context; the technically correct plural of “Ḥadīth” is ’aḥādīth but obviously accept Ḥadīths]
metadata: the “other victim” is the telesecularist TV host Islām al-Buḥayrī, whom Sisi pardoned
While debating this point on television, Mizo once infamously allegedly threatened to beat up his interlocutor with an offstage hammer

bonuses.leadin: They can be used to study reactions with half-lives as short as a few milliseconds. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these instruments which force a fixed volume of reactants into a mixing chamber and monitor the reaction spectroscopically.

Because they can monitor such fast reactions, stopped-flow instruments are often used in the study of reactions catalysed by this biological molecules, whose kinetics are described by the Michaelis-Menten model.
A key assumption of the Michaelis-Menten model is that the concentration of enzyme-substrate complex is both very small and has this property.

bonuses.leadin: This collection includes stories about a Hungarian baron who has an incestuous relationship with his daughters, and a wife who experiences a placebo effect from a fake aphrodisiac at the cinema. For 10 points each:
answers: erotic fiction [accept erotica, or answers that get at “sex”] <Theo>
parts: Name this posthumous collection of fifteen stories, including Marcel and The Basque and Bijou. It was written for a client known as ‘The Collector’.
Delta of Venus is a work of this writer and essayist, who wrote about her affair with Henry Miller. She is also known for the collection Little Birds and the novella A Spy in the House of Love.
Delta of Venus is a work of this genre, of which Nin is one of the most celebrated proponents. Other writers in this sometimes taboo genre include Carol Queen and E.L. James.

bonuses.leadin: This album records a concert imprudently scheduled for the same night as a Rocky Marciano fight, and Charlie Parker played on this album under the pseudonym “Charlie Chan.” For 10 points each:
answers: drums [prompt on parts of a drum-kit e.g. cymbals asking “what is that part of?”]
parts: Name this live album, the sole recording by “the Quintet,” a bebop supergroup that included Parker, Charles Mingus, and Bud Powell. Named for its Toronto venue, it is often called “the greatest jazz concert ever.”

The Quintet’s player of this instrument was Max Roach, who formed the ensemble M’Boom with Joe Chambers. This instrument’s modern form was pioneered by Armand Zildjian and a frequent collaborator of Benny Goodman.

The final member of “the Quintet” was this “Salt Peanuts”-shouting, Cab Calloway-stabbing, bent trumpet- playing, cheek-puffing virtuoso. This composer of “A Night in Tunisia” was one of bebop’s main pioneers.
answers_formatted: drums [prompt on parts of a drum-kit e.g. cymbals asking “what is that part of?]
promptable: parts of a drum-kit e.g. cymbals asking “what is that part of?

bonuses.leadin: Lagrange’s theorem states that the number of elements in a subgroup divides the number of elements in a group – but the converse doesn’t necessarily hold. For 10 points each:
parts: One example that disproves the converse is the group A4, which lacks a subgroup of order 6 despite having this number of elements. Since A4 contains half of the permutations on 4 objects, this number is equal to half of 4 factorial.

However, if a prime p divides the order of a group, there exists a subgroup of order p thanks to a theorem named for this French mathematician, the prior namesake of an inequality relating inner products and magnitudes.

A theorem named for this man states that for a finite solvable group of order n, and for d and n-over-d coprime integers, the group has a namesake subgroup of order d. He also names a ‘marriage theorem’ in combinatorics.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about classical Indian philosophy, for 10 points each:
parts: Indian philosophy’s approach to this field centers on a set of six pramanas, with different schools of thought defined in part by which ones they accept. This field investigates what knowledge is and how one knows things.

The Vaisheshika relied on the two pramanas of “perception” and “inference” and promoted a type of this position based on the concept of paramāṇu. Leucippus founded the Greek school of thought known by this term.

This thinker argued that language produces the illusion of hierarchical binary opposites 1800 years ahead of Derrida. This founder of the Buddhist Madhyamaka school was a key proponent of the two truths doctrine.

bonuses.leadin: This man claimed descent from George Castriot, and at one point went by Castriot’s nickname of Iskander Bey. For 10 points each:
answers: King Zog I [also accept Ahmet Zogu or Ahmet Muhtar Zogolli]
Gjakmarrja [or blood-taking; also accept Albanian blood feuds; prompt on feuds and equivalents like vendettas] <JS>
parts: Name this aristocrat, rival of Fan Noli, and ruler of his nation, who instituted a namesake military salute where the right hand is placed over the heart, with the palm facing downwards. [Note: do the salute]
Zog ruled as Prime Minister, then President, then finally King of this Balkan country.

The number of assassination attempts on Zog can be partly explained by his being the subject of around 600 of these social obligations, from which people often tried to escape by staying in kulla ngujimi or “locked towers.”
answers_formatted: King Zog I [also accept Ahmet Zogu or Ahmet Muhtar Zogolli]
Gjakmarrja <JS> [or blood-taking; also accept Albanian blood feuds; prompt on feuds or equivalents like vendettas]

bonuses.leadin: Unlike a similar substance, it contains the bases A, C, G and U. For 10 points each:
answers: TPP Riboswitch [or THI element or Thi-box riboswitch]
parts: Name this substance whose messenger form is produced in transcription.
RNA forms this highly conserved secondary structure that binds directly to an activated thiamine derivative to reglate gene expression in archaea, bacteria and eukaryotes.
RNAs can act as guide strands in this incredibly trendy system for genome editing which allows DNA to cut a cell’s DNA at a desired location.

bonuses.leadin: One holder of this political office was appointed to it after having served as Theresa May’s parliamentary campaign manager. For ten points each:
parts: Name this political office held by Gavin Williamson prior to his appointment as Secretary of Defence in November 2017. The holder of this office typically also serves as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury.
During his time as Chief Whip, Williamson gained notoriety for the presence on his desk of his pet Cronus, an animal of this specific type.
Following Williamson’s promotion to the Ministry of Defence, this man replaced him as the Government’s Chief Whip, and is the current holder of the office.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, cast your yarn onto your needles and answer the following about knitting:
answers: stocking stitch [or stockinette, do not accept reverse stocking stitch]
parts: Knitting is based on two fundamental stitches – the imaginatively named “knit”, and this stitch, usually abbreviated p. This stitch is the inverse of a knit stitch.

Knitting on the right side of the work and purling on the wrong side of the work produces this sort of stitch pattern. This pattern and garter stitch are often the first two patterns learnt by beginners.

One way to add colour to knitting is to use this method, which shares its name with a woodworking technique. When using this technique to inlay colours, yarns are left hanging rather than carried across like in Fair Isle.
answers_formatted: stocking stitch [or stockinette, do not accept reverse stocking stitch]
acceptable: stockinette, do not accept reverse stocking stitch

bonuses.leadin: The daggers and bare hands of one group in this painting contrasts with the scimitars and sabres of another group, some of whom have been dragged from their horses. For 10 points each:
answers: The Second of May, 1808 in Madrid: The Charge of the Mamelukes [or El Dos de Mayo, 1808 en Madrid: La Lucha con/Carga de los Mamelucos; accept either underlined portion in Spanish or English; accept any answer that gets across a fight with or charge by the Mamelukes of the French Imperial Guard, do not accept Third of May]
stigmata [prompt on answers like holes or wounds]
parts: Name this 1814 painting, which depicts a conflict between a crowd and a group of mounted soldiers, one of whom is being stabbed at the painting's centre, during the title uprising.

The Second of May, 1808 is a companion painting to The Third of May, 1808, whose soon to be executed central figure wears a contrastingly bright white shirt and has this feature on one of his outstretched hands.
Both The Second of May, 1808 and The Third of May, 1808 were painted by this Spanish artist, also known for his Disasters of War series and his “Black Paintings.”
answers_formatted: The Second of May, 1808 in Madrid: The Charge of the Mamelukes [or El Dos de Mayo, 1808 en Madrid: La Lucha con/Carga de los Mamelucos; accept either underlined portion in Spanish or English; accept any answer that gets across a fight with or charge by the Mamelukes of the French Imperial Guard, do not or Third of May]
acceptable: The Second of May, 1808 in Madrid: The Charge of the Mamelukes
Second of May, 1808 in Madrid: The Charge of the Mamelukes
El Dos de Mayo, 1808 en Madrid: La Lucha con/Carga de los Mamelucos
any answer that gets across a fight with
charge by the Mamelukes of the French Imperial Guard, do not

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some actors who have played characters of many different nationalities, and indeed ethnicities, across their careers.
parts: This actor played a Jewish accountant in Schindler’s List and an Iranian former soldier in House of Sand and Fog, though he is most known for his Oscar-winning portrayal of Mahatma Gandhi.

This actor played an Afghan attorney general in Whisky Tango Foxtrot, Mexican artist Diego Rivera in Frida, the mayor of a French village in Chocolat, and Spanish bishop Manuel Aringarosa in The Da Vinci Code.
This actor played Islamic Sharif Mulai Ahmed er Raisuni in The Wind and the Lion, and Spanish nobleman Juan Sánchez Villa-Lobos Ramírez in Highlander.

bonuses.leadin: A book may be “on yellow paper” in several different senses. For 10 points each:
parts: The Yellow Book, a quarterly literary periodical in 1890s London, was literally yellow. Its first art editor was this illustrator of Salomé, whose drawings often featured inappropriate details that annoyed John Lane.

In a short story by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, the protagonist is confined to a yellow wallpapered room by her husband in an attempt to cure her of this mental illness, characterised by chronic low mood and lethargy.

This English author explored rather different themes in her Novel on Yellow Paper, telling of a bored secretary named Pompey who visits Germany and is shocked into interrogating her own anti-Semitism.
